sections.heading: State charter. A veteran service organization shall be considered state chartered when the organization meets all of the requirements listed in this Act and the organization's application for state charter status has been approved by the Attorney General

sections.heading: Granting of state charter status
sections.text: The Attorney General shall grant state charter status to any organization that has demonstrated that all requirements for obtaining state charter status have been met.

sections.heading: Application for state charter status
sections.text: A veteran service organization may submit an application for state charter status to the Attorney General. All supporting documentation demonstrating that each of the requirements listed in this Act have been met shall be provided with the application.

sections.text: Attestation of compliance. Any application for state charter status shall include the following statement, on organizational letterhead and signed by all officers: "All officers for (insert lawful organizational name) do hereby attest that all requirements for a state charter have been met, that there are no past or ongoing enforcement actions or lawsuits against the organization or any of its officers for violations or suspected violations of the Consumer Fraud and Deceptive Business Practices Act, or the Military Veterans Assistance Act, and that we will notify the Attorney General within 30 days if, at any point, the organization no longer meets one or more of the requirements for state charter status."

sections.heading: Denial of state charter. The Attorney General shall deny an application for state charter status to any organization that does not meet all the requirements for state charter status in Section 15

sections.heading: Duration of state charter status
sections.text: State charter status shall be valid for 3 years. A veteran service organization must reapply for state charter status at least 120 days prior to the expiration of its current state charter status.

sections.heading: Revocation. If the Attorney General is made aware, either through notification as provided in Section 30 or through other information or evidence, that an organization that has been granted state charter status no longer meets one or more of the requirements of Section 15, the Attorney General may r
sections.text: Revocation. If the Attorney General is made aware, either through notification as provided in Section 30 or through other information or evidence, that an organization that has been granted state charter status no longer meets one or more of the requirements of Section 15, the Attorney General may revoke the state charter status. Nothing in this Section is intended to take away or limit any powers of the Attorney General under common law or other statutory law, and the Attorney General may, in his or her sole discretion, request that a court revoke state charter status based on other conduct not specifically listed in this Section.

sections.heading: Publication of state chartered veteran service organizations
sections.text: The Attorney General shall maintain a publicly accessible list of state chartered veteran service organizations.

sections.heading: Violation; remedies. It is a violation of Section 9 of the Military Veterans Assistance Act for any person, group, or entity to assert state charter status where such status has not been granted in accordance with this Act or where such status has been revoked
